explode.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to burst, or to make something burst, into small pieces, usually with a loud noise and in a way that causes damage
explode.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The device was thrown at an army patrol but failed to explode.
Far sooner than anyone thought possible, the Russians exploded an atomic bomb.
explode.translation[0].definitions[0].no: In everyday English, people usually say that a bomb goes off rather than explodes:
A bomb went off in the city centre.
explode.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to suddenly increase greatly in number, amount, or degree
explode.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Florida’s population exploded after World War II.
explode.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to suddenly express strong feelings such as anger
explode.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Paul exploded. ‘What has it got to do with you?’ he yelled.
She exploded with grief and anger.
He told a joke which made Hank explode with laughter.
He exploded into a screaming, kicking rage.
explode.translation[0].definitions[3].de: if a situation explodes, it is suddenly no longer controlled, and is often violent
explode.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: Riots may explode at any time.
The continued tension could explode into more violence.
explode.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to make a very loud noise
explode.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: A clap of thunder exploded overhead.
explode.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: to explode
explode
if a bomb explodes, it bursts suddenly and violently with a loud noise
A bomb exploded in a crowded metro station this morning, killing five people.
go off
if a bomb goes off, it explodes. Go off is less formal than explode and is the usual phrase to use in everyday English
Luckily the station was empty when the bomb went off.
As many as ten bombs went off across the city, most of them car bombs.
blow up
if a building, car, plane etc blows up, it bursts suddenly and violently into pieces, causing a lot of damage
The plane blew up in mid-air, killing all the passengers and crew.
In early 1986, a US space shuttle blew up shortly after launch.
erupt
if a volcano erupts, it explodes and sends smoke and rock into the sky
The volcano has erupted at least fifteen times since 1883.
burst
if something that has air or liquid inside it bursts, it explodes and the air or liquid comes out
One of the water pipes had burst.
The plane caught fire after its tyre burst on landing.
to make something explode
explode
to make a bomb burst suddenly and violently with a loud noise
The terrorists planned to explode a car bomb outside the US embassy.
set off
to make a bomb explode, either deliberately or accidentally. Set off is less formal than explode and is the usual phrase to use in everyday English
The group set off a bomb outside a crowded cafe in Izmir last September.
Police say radio signals were probably used to set the bomb off.
detonate
to make a bomb explode, especially by using special equipment. Detonate is a more technical word than set off
Army experts detonated the bomb safely in a nearby field.
The 200 kg bomb was detonated by terrorists using a remote-control device.
let off
to deliberately make a bomb explode
Terrorists let off a bomb in the city centre.
The bomb was let off shortly before 3 pm.
blow up
to make a building, car, plane etc explode
He was involved in a plot to blow up a passenger jet.
He struck a match and blew the whole place up.
